body: Updated. Fixed description and offset is now a full WVec, allowing custom X/Y position as well (updated TS Titan as showcase).
Updated.
I'm really not a fan of having separate `CenterPosition` and `TargetCenterPosition`s.  CenterPosition being at the bottom of the actor is a bug, and should be fixed properly for all cases.

> I'm really not a fan of having separate CenterPosition and TargetCenterPositions. CenterPosition being at the bottom of the actor is a bug, and should be fixed properly for all cases.

I see your point, but wouldn't that cause all kinds of regressions with pathfinding, attack distance and so on (at least in TS)? Problems like #5841 could become more common and I'm not sure I'd manage to find and fix them all (not on my own, in any case).

I made a quick test locally, and among other things, `AnimationWithOffset` is positioned relative to `Actor.CenterPosition`. Generally speaking, In my opinion using `Actor.CenterPosition` for everything is just asking for trouble and regressions.

But more importantly, after some thinking I'd like to point out this:
If someone (maybe myself) where to add SW:Empire at War / Universe at War-style hit zones, then splitting targeting points from CenterPosition would become mandatory anyway.

My idea in that regard is to refactor the `Health` trait into a `HitPoint` of which an actor can have multiple ones, and only when health/HP of all (or at least all required) HitPoints has been reduced to 0 is the actor considered 'killed'.
I'd allow modders to assign `Armor` types to a specific `HitPoint`, give `HitPoint` a customizable `Priority` property (HitPoints with higher priority would be attacked first, if multiple HitPoints have the same priority, the attacker switches between them randomly), and a `RequiredForKill` property together with adding a property to warheads to ignore certain `HitPoint`s.
That could be used to implement StarCraft-style shields as well, among other nice things. 
Could come in quite handy for my MechCommander RTS mod as well. I guess I'll make a ticket.

> But more importantly, after some thinking I'd like to point out this:
> If someone (maybe myself) where to add SW:Empire at War / Universe at War-style hit zones, then splitting targeting points from CenterPosition would become mandatory anyway.

We already have a system in place for this: the `ITargetablePositions` interface and `Target.Positions`.
Just wanted to note that I'm still working on this, using `ITargetablePositions` as suggested. It's just not ready yet.

Updated.

No idea how the commit order got messed up (commit 3 should be commit 5), but that shouldn't have any effect as long as you don't test the first 5 commits individually.

Updated.

`TargetPositionOffset` is now actually relative to body orientation. 
Used to fix the TS weed harvester's target position to match the voxel.
> OpenRA.Mods.Common/Traits/Health.cs:L108: [SP2000] Invalid spacing at the end of the line.
Fixed style issue.
Needs a rebase.
Rebased.
Can we add a height / offset for infantry too? You should be able to set it once on the default with something reasonable.
Having actors not shoot at eachother's feet / wheels is a subtle but very nice polish improvement :smile:

@pchote: Fixed the factory offsets.

About infantry, I only gave them a 'ceiling' but left the target position at ground for now.
Two reasons:
1) TS' machine gun impact and anti-tank warhead explosions are visually designed for hitting flat surfaces, so while it looks good enough for vehicles and buildings, it looks rather weird on infantry.
2) Infantry prone sequences show them flat on the ground and - just like tick tanks - we'll need upgradable HitShapes + a tie to the prone logic to cover this properly, and I don't want to open that can of worms in this PR.

I got:

```

  at OpenRA.Mods.Common.Warheads.CreateEffectWarhead.GetDirectHit (OpenRA.World world, CPos cell, WPos pos, OpenRA.Actor firedBy, Boolean checkTargetType) <0x422b2680 + 0x0010f> in <filename unknown>:0
```

when shooting down an Orca Bomber with a SAM site. Not sure if it is related though.

`CreateEffectWarhead` doesn't use Linq on bleed, so it must be caused by cb3a760.

I'm not sure under which circumstances the Sequence can contain no elements there, I couldn't reproduce the crash so far.

Rebased and updated. I suspect that `var healthInfo = unit.Info.TraitInfos<HealthInfo>();` never returned `null`, so the following null check never triggered.

That should be fixed now.
Seems to work fine now. :white_check_mark:

As requested by @pchote I have split this up into less intimidating, more reviewable chunks.

#11168 first, then this, then #11169.
Updated.

Do you intend to use/have a usecase for the Footprint targetable position? I can understand why did you made the restriction, however, it seems really useless with it and all the cases where I'd even think about using it could be resolved with a bit of math/trial-and-error on CenterPosition offset even.

With all in mind, I probably would be more okay with dropping/removing it atm instead of merging it in it's unfinished state.

> Do you intend to use/have a usecase for the Footprint targetable position?

Not really, I just preserved the old `TargetablePositions` from `Building` that way. Personally I agree that we probably don't need it, but maybe we're overlooking something. Could you chime in on this @pchote ?

Oh wait, now I remember what that was supposed to do which might even break on this PR: if a unit has lower range than the building width, the unit might be unable to reach the targeting position and thereby attack the building (say, melee units).

You're right, and unfortunately it really breaks on this PR.
Setting the type to Footprint fixes the targeting, but then weapons aim at the first (top-left) cell of the footprint. This will need to be fixed, obviously.

Updated.

The underlying issue of what @GraionDilach pointed out is that on bleed, targeting and actual attacking aim at different position types. Using `TargetablePositions` for everything would have broken that separation, and using something hacky like first pos for targeting, 2nd pos for attacking felt wrong, so in oder to keep the regression risk low and the separation intact, I decided to introduce an additional `IAttackablePositions` interface that basically works like `TargetablePositions`, but allows to leave the latter as-is and not cause any trouble there.

In addition to that, things like `Armament` no longer just aim at the first `AttackablePosition`, but rather the closest one to the source by default (unless this behavior is disabled). Later, when we have a Footprint HitShape, we can use this to reproduce D2k-like shooting at the closest cell of a building rather than the center.
Updated.

ok, looks fine so far. Three more things to note, though:
1. Could you mention a use case for `Armament.IgnoreAttackablePositionOffset` in the commit message of the second-to-last commit, please?
2. Could you please describe (in its commit message) which problem the last commit is supposed to solve? Also, does that depend on the equivalent setting on `Armament` to be set as well? I imagine that otherwise the barrel of a turret could look one way while it would shoot the other.
3. I'm not too sure if I like this `AttackablePositions` thing living on `Health`. Would `Targetable` work instead, for example?

Targetable doesn't care about the physical properties of the unit (hitshapes and stuff). The best solution could prolly be to decouple hitshapes and all related from Health into a new trait (especially if multiple health traits arrive which I guess @reaperrr do wants).
